items.title: Ecuadorians to Vote on Constitutional Rewrite, Possibly Gutting Rights of Nature
items.description: In 2008, Ecuador made history by enshrining the rights of nature in its constitution, recognizing ecosystems as living entities with legal rights.  For nearly two decades, Indigenous communities and environmentalists have defended these rights, setting a global example. items.description: One September morning Jim Fulton was pumping fuel into a combine harvester and watching the sky for rain.  Fulton’s family has been farming in Illinois since the 1890s. items.title: This Texas Family Designed Their House Around the Solar Cycle Nearly 30 Years Ago
items.description: Some 30 years ago, Paul and Elena Westbrook considered the earth’s rotations around the sun to make a big life choice: where to build a home.  Tracking where the solar noon would land on their property throughout the year proved clever. items.title: Central Maine Power Faces Backlash Over Proposed Rate Hikes and Shareholder Profits
items.description: Frustrated ratepayers and climate activists gathered in Freeport, Maine, last week to protest yet another rate hike proposal by Central Maine Power.  CMP’s proposal, submitted to the Maine Public Utilities Commission in September, would raise electricity rates over the next five years, generating roughly $1.4 billion in additional revenue to fund grid reliability and efficiency […]

items.title: Ohio Has Invested Millions in Wetlands to Catch Nutrient Runoff From Farms. A New Report Suggests It’s Working.
items.description: A new report on purpose-built wetlands in Ohio showcases their success in reducing nutrient runoff from farms, validating millions of dollars’ worth of efforts to combat toxic algal blooms. Researchers with the H2Ohio Wetland Monitoring Program developed the report, which uses data from 10 wetlands that have been restored since the H2Ohio program launched in […]

items.title: Gulf South Residents and Green Groups Sue Trump and EPA Over Toxic Air Pollution Exemptions
